content.raw:
From the error message, it sounds like the name attribute (ie. `<joint name="...">`) is the same for at least two of the joints in your model. Currently gazebo requires these attributes to have unique names (ie. joint0, joint1, joint2, etc).

Is that the problem?
content.html:
From the error message, it sounds like the name attribute (ie. <joint name="...">) is the same for at least two of the joints in your model. Currently gazebo requires these attributes to have unique names (ie. joint0, joint1, joint2, etc).

Is that the problem?

content.raw:
No, all joints have different names. The only problem is that the joints form a parallel mechanism.

If you try building a simple 4-bar linkage SDF you can replicate the error message.
content.html:
No, all joints have different names. The only problem is that the joints form a parallel mechanism.

If you try building a simple 4-bar linkage SDF you can replicate the error message.

content.raw: Can you share a simple form of your model to help us replicate the error message?

content.raw: I was just discussing this with @hsu, and you have to be careful when doing loops in urdf. We'll modify this example to illustrate a workaround. Thanks for posting it.
content.html: I was just discussing this with @hsu, and you have to be careful when doing loops in urdf. We'll modify this example to illustrate a workaround. Thanks for posting it.

content.raw:
I copied your urdf into a file called parallel.urdf and did `gzsdf print parallel.urdf > parallel.sdf`. Here is a subset of the sdf:
~~~
$ grep -A2 '<joint' parallel.sdf
    <joint name='LegL' type='revolute'>
      <child>LegL</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
--
    <joint name='TracksLL' type='revolute'>
      <child>TracksLeft</child>
      <parent>LegL0</parent>
--
    <joint name='legl0' type='revolute'>
      <child>LegL0</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
--
    <joint name='TracksLL' type='revolute'>
      <child>TracksLeft</child>
      <parent>LegL0</parent>
~~~
As you can see, the TracksLL joint is repeated two times, and the TracksL joint is not included at all. I believe this is based on the hierarchical data structure in urdf that does not allow for loops. There is a workaround using `<gazebo>` tags, but I haven't implemented it yet.

As an alternative example, I believe the [pr2_gripper in gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/68989fe22ddc430909763eace37d45a4a4936e25/pr2_gripper/model.sdf?at=default) has a parallel mechanism, though it is expressed in sdf rather than urdf.
content.html:
I copied your urdf into a file called parallel.urdf and did gzsdf print parallel.urdf > parallel.sdf. Here is a subset of the sdf:

$ grep -A2 '<joint' parallel.sdf
    <joint name='LegL' type='revolute'>
      <child>LegL</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
--
    <joint name='TracksLL' type='revolute'>
      <child>TracksLeft</child>
      <parent>LegL0</parent>
--
    <joint name='legl0' type='revolute'>
      <child>LegL0</child>
      <parent>base_link</parent>
--
    <joint name='TracksLL' type='revolute'>
      <child>TracksLeft</child>
      <parent>LegL0</parent>

As you can see, the TracksLL joint is repeated two times, and the TracksL joint is not included at all. I believe this is based on the hierarchical data structure in urdf that does not allow for loops. There is a workaround using <gazebo> tags, but I haven't implemented it yet.

As an alternative example, I believe the pr2_gripper in gazebo_models has a parallel mechanism, though it is expressed in sdf rather than urdf.

content.raw:
Ok, it all became clear after looking at the pr2_gripper!

Thanks very much for your input! I think it would be a great addition in the wiki page for new users!

I think a parser like urdf_to_graphiz (sdf_to_graphiz) would help in the development of proper sdf files for robots!

Thanks again!
content.html:
Ok, it all became clear after looking at the pr2_gripper!

Thanks very much for your input! I think it would be a great addition in the wiki page for new users!

I think a parser like urdf_to_graphiz (sdf_to_graphiz) would help in the development of proper sdf files for robots!

Thanks again!

content.raw: Using SDF models assigning <pose> in joint loops can create parallel mechanisms.
content.html: Using SDF models assigning <pose> in joint loops can create parallel mechanisms.

content.raw: How do you fix this problem from the urdf code? Thanks!
content.html: How do you fix this problem from the urdf code? Thanks!

content.raw:
Urdf does not support parallel mechanisms. There is no workaround on the
URDF/ROS side. You can only build a parallel gazebo model.
content.html: Urdf does not support parallel mechanisms. There is no workaround on the URDF/ROS side. You can only build a parallel gazebo model.

content.raw: This can be “worked around” in URDF by using the `<gazebo>` tag and putting all the joints that close the loops inside this tag. The joints have to be, however, in SDF format. In URDF, you won’t get the joints, but if you use `gzsdf`, you’ll have an almost working URDF model and fully working SDF model.
content.html: This can be “worked around” in URDF by using the <gazebo> tag and putting all the joints that close the loops inside this tag. The joints have to be, however, in SDF format. In URDF, you won’t get the joints, but if you use gzsdf, you’ll have an almost working URDF model and fully working SDF model.
